Comments_List: I learned to read Coptic relatively fluently (with lexical aids) and I have developed a further appreciation for the ambiguities inherent in the language.

The class was extremely strong in the areas of analyzing sentences, allowing for variant translations when the language is ambiguous, and parsing verbs. I recognize that our class was diverse in ability and previous experience and Professor Schmidt did an excellent job of handling the wide range of students, but there were days that I wished that we could have moved faster and, compared to what I've heard from other Coptic classes in previous years, this class was behind. We didn't make it through the book's passage of Mark, which made studying for the final test convenient, but it was also slightly frustrating because I've heard other classes made it to other sources outside the text.

I would definitely recommend this course to another student. It definitely taught me what I expected to learn through the class and it was an enjoyable and comfortable place in which to learn a language that was, in many ways, completely unfamiliar.
